note: H. B. Swete is believed to be the author of this article.
title: I am indebted for most of my details about Theodore’s life to the article “Theodorus” in Smith and Wace

In his article, Swete opines that Theodore “stands out among ancient expositors of Scripture almost alone – that of an independent inquirer, provided with a true method of eliciting the sense of his author, and considerable skill in the use of it
For a contemporary study of Theodore and the sources of his life, see Guida

Theodore was most likely educated at the academy of Libanius, one the elite rhetorical teachers in the Byzantine empire. 5 For a theological assessment of what happened at the Council of Ephesus, see Kelly (1978: 323–30). It is important to keep in mind that “Cyril’s Twelve Anathemas were formally read out at the session on 22 June, but there seems to have been no move to canonize them along with his second letter
For works that treat in some depth the historical and theological background of this period, see Murphy and Sherwood (1974) and Grillmeier
For a general history of Antioch in antiquity, see Downey
This has recently been translated into English by Robert Hill
